messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 50 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: ùëò-span weakly leveled planarity

Paper Abstract: Abstract This paper studies planar drawings of graphs in which each vertex is represented as a point along a sequence of horizontal lines, called levels, and each edge is either a horizontal segment or a strictly yùë¶y-monotone curve. A graph is sùë†s-span weakly leveled planar if it admits such a drawing where the edges have span at most sùë†s; the span of an edge is the number of levels it touches minus one. We investigate the problem of computing sùë†s-span weakly leveled planar drawings from both the computational and the combinatorial perspectives. We prove the problem to be para-NP-hard with respect to its natural parameter sùë†s and investigate its complexity with respect to widely used structural parameters. We show the existence of a polynomial-size kernel with respect to vertex cover number and prove that the problem is FPT when parameterized by treedepth. We also present upper and lower bounds on the span for various graph classes. Notably, we show that cycle trees, a family of 222-outerplanar graphs generalizing Halin graphs, are Œò‚Äã(log‚Å°n)Œòùëõ\Theta(\log n)-span weakly leveled planar and 444-span weakly leveled planar when 333-connected. As a byproduct of these combinatorial results, we obtain improved bounds on the edge-length ratio of the graph families under consideration.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 50 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 50"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Bounding and computing obstacle numbers of graphs",
        "Track layouts, layered path decompositions, and leveled planarity",
        "Layered drawings of digraphs",
        "On the upward book thickness problem: Combinatorial and complexity results",
        "Parameterized algorithms for book embedding problems",
        "Parameterized algorithms for queue layouts",
        "Small drawings of outerplanar graphs, series-parallel graphs, and other planar graphs",
        "Height-preserving transformations of planar graph drawings",
        "On the edge-length ratio of 2-trees",
        "On edge-length ratios of partial 2-trees",
        "A partial kùëòk-arboretum of graphs with bounded treewidth",
        "Convex drawings of 3-connected plane graphs",
        "On the edge-length ratio of planar graphs",
        "On the planar edge-length ratio of planar graphs",
        "Level-planar drawings with few slopes",
        "Tree drawings revisited",
        "Planar drawings with few slopes of halin graphs and nested pseudotrees",
        "Parameterized algorithms for upward planarity",
        "Asymptotic enumeration and limit laws for graphs of fixed genus",
        "Convex grid drawings of 3-connected planar graphs",
        "A note on optimal area algorithms for upward drawings of binary trees",
        "Square-contact representations of partial 2-trees and triconnected simply-nested graphs",
        "How to draw a planar graph on a grid",
        "Graph Drawing: Algorithms for the Visualization of Graphs",
        "Hierarchies and planarity theory",
        "New bounds on the local and global edge-length ratio of planar graphs, 2023",
        "Graph Theory, 4th Edition, volume 173 of Graduate texts in mathematics",
        "On the parameterized complexity of layered graph drawing",
        "Planar graphs have bounded queue-number",
        "Track layouts of graphs",
        "Straight-line drawings on restricted integer grids in two and three dimensions",
        "Kernelization: Theory of Parameterized Preprocessing",
        "Drawing graphs in the plane with high resolution",
        "Lower bounds on the area requirements of series-parallel graphs",
        "On straight lines representation of planar graphs",
        "Laying out graphs using queues",
        "Exact crossing number parameterized by vertex cover",
        "Quality ratios of measures for graph drawing styles",
        "Linear time algorithm for isomorphism of planar graphs (preliminary report)",
        "Upward and orthogonal planarity are w[1]-hard parameterized by treewidth",
        "Drawing planar graphs using the canonical ordering",
        "On the edge-length ratio of outerplanar graphs",
        "On the angular resolution of planar graphs",
        "Die Baumweite von Graphen als ein Ma√ü f√ºr die Kompliziertheit algorithmischer Probleme",
        "Linear and Planar Arrangements of Graphs",
        "Methods for visual understanding of hierarchical system structures",
        "On embedding a graph in the grid with the minimum number of bends",
        "Handbook on Graph Drawing and Visualization",
        "How to draw a graph",
        "Parameterized analysis and crossing minimization problems"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 50 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in ùëò-span weakly leveled planarity, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
